Medium body and OK aftertaste. A smooth, balanced and very drinkable dark lager. 

  
  
Previous rating: 7-4-6-3-10

It’s a HELL of a lot better than the Budweiser we know. Budvar is supposedly THE original Budweiser. This dark lager was pretty good. It pours a nice dark brown with a smooth head that goes away quickly. The aroma was above average. It would have been better if it didn’t have that typical green bottle skunky smell. It doesn’t taste skunky at all thankfully. The finish is good. Overall, a good beer that would probably be better if it was in a brown bottle. I’ll have to try this on tap someday.

Bottle from Oddbins.  Pours dark brown with beige head that quickly dissipates.  Roasted malt predominates in the nose but reveals nice hop characteristics (Saaz) on closer inspection.  The initial hit is of roast malts eventually being balanced by a hint of sweetness.  Long hoppy finish.  Despite its appearance and the use of stout-type malts the end result is surprisingly light.  Fantastic stuff and, if you can find it, the cask version is even better.
Bottle: Poured a black color with a thin light brown head. Aroma is thick coffee bean and roasted malts. Taste is coffee thick black with a bitter finish that keeps the tongue lively.

Bottle 50cl, Oddbins.  Dark dark dark appearance.  Thin lacing - short lasting head.  Sweetish aroma.  Roasted taste, a bit nutty.  A little chocolaty.  Would have preferred it to be stronger to give it a bit of more character, but nonetheless a good decent beer.

(Draught on 2008-08-08) Deep dark brown. Clear.  Tan-coloured medium-sized head. Malts and metallic aromas in nosw. Medium-bodied dry palate with lot of carbonation. Malts, bitterness, roasty flavours and sweetness. Harsh and bitter aftertaste.

0,5 l bottle. Reddish black colored. Very big, nice and foamy head. Very easy going, smooth Dunkel, with the usual set of aromas included : nuts, roasted malts, dark chocolate, caramel. Bitter aftertaste. Like the others have said, a bit boring but then again quite good dark beer.
Bottle. Red dark brown colour with a beige head. Aroma is sweet, malt, caramel. Flavour is sweet, roasted, coffe, caramel. A little bit boring beer.

No 465

Rated: 16.07.2008

Bottle green, 500 ml

Appearance: Pours reddish, dark, deep and perfectly clear body texture, carbonation of the body is rather mild, head is off white, cappuccino like in colour, there is decent lacing, head is frothy in texture, initially medium, slowly decreasing to small but still lasting as a small beige - brown cloud on the body surface.

Aroma: Very mild and gentle aroma of dark slightly toasted malt notes of chockolate, caramel, coffee, nice dark character, cappuccino, a note of Plzen malty touch at the background manifesting itself in grainy accents.

Flavour: Very pleasant roasted barley grains, strong bitterness binding your tongue of hoppy origin is that what creates an adventurous experience of dark chockolate and cacao. Very clean, focused and well rounded ingredients. When it comes to maltyness: Plzen malt, Munich malt, caramel malt, burned, roasted malt is balanced with herbal hoppy nose of Saaz hops. Some minerality. Finish duration is long. Very nice coffee and dark chockolate finish with gentle warmth on palate. Alcohol is perfectly hidden.

Palate: Body is light to medium, texture is wattery to dry, finish feel is chalky, medium astringent with nice herbal Saaz hoppy and a bit smoked nose and long bitterness on palate, no alcohol in taste but slight warmth is felt on palate, great brewmaster job.

Bottle. A clear, dark brown beer with a beige head. Slightly oxidizied aroma with a little touch of smoke. Sure on the malty side, could use a little more balance, but quite good. The flavor is on the other hand a bit boring, roasted and malty, lacking on the hops and bitterness. Coffee-like finish. Medium body with a decent carbonation level. Except for the "dark" part, the beer is quite boring. Easy to drink though. (080620)

Bottle 0,5l. Dark ruby red colored - almost black. A large creamy tanned head. Pleasant aroma of nuts and malt. Modest flavor of biscuit and malt - like bread. An evolving nutty and fruity dry aftertaste with hints of coffee and chocolate. Refreshing and quite good. KI=6.
Bottle. Big brown head with roasted malts and chocolate. Easy to drink and not too sweet to have a few in one sitting. Carbonation is light and taste is yet one-dimensional but good.

Bottle.
Clear orange brown coloured with a huge beige head.
Sweet aroma of caramel, malts and hay with notes of dried fruits and butter.
Sweet and light roasted flavour of caramel and hay with notes of dried fruits and cardboard.
Roasted and hoppy finish.

On Draft in Prague - Tyn Court. Pours a clear dark brown, large head quickly going down. Nutty caramel taste but smooth, roasted malts. Slightly bitter aftertaste. Ok, didn’t seem to have enough body to me.
On tap in prague, not my favourite of the czech darks but taste of smooth nutty chocolate, with dry aftertaste. Had in bottle today and decided it tastes better on a cold day

On tap in Prague.
Nutty, malty, lots of grain. Sweet, a bit too dessert-like, but not at all bad. More for winter drinking, perhpas.

Appearance: Dark, dark brown. A lot of head, though shortlived.
Aroma: Malty. Raisins. Coffee.
Taste: Malt and coffee-ish. Bitter. Smooth.
Info: 500ml bottle, 15/9-2006, 3/300M

[Nitrokeg at the RISC Global Cafe, Reading] A hint of dusty, gone-off plain chocolate, but overwhelming flavour is a metallic bitterness.  Some ash and sourness comes through in aftertaste, leaving a very dry mouthfeel, but overall this is pretty unpleasant.  In all the court cases between the Czech Budweiser/Budvar brand and the giant A-B, we were all secretly rooting for the little guy, the Czech company.  But in return for our support, they’ve gone mass market and this now tastes like grim, weak, macro swill.  Thanks guys.
500 ml bottle. Deep brown color, big tan head. Aroma of roasted malts. Pretty light body, with more roasted malts and a suggestion of coffee. Not bad.

Draft at The Spaniards on the Heath. Dark brown color with orange/garnet hilites. Creamy light tan head. Dark toasted malt aroma. Near full bodied with medium carbonation. It is balanced, but whether from hop or burnt malt I cannot say. Suugests the old Guinness in a way, but with a different bitter.
Pours a deep dark brown.  Aromas of roasted malts, smoke, and hints of fruit.  Flavors of the roasted malts, some fruit, with a coffee aftertaste.

Toasted brown with a loose tan fluff.  Semi-sharp chocolate and coffee melds with a distinct nuttiness, toasted bread and light smokiness.  Roasted and nutty from the start; mild caramel sweetness before a dry espresso finish.  Stealthy, light; velvety with crisp carbonation.
Pleasantly dry, roasty and sessionable.
50 cl bottle, best before 5.2.2009.
Nice foamy top. Almost completely black. The aroma is not as strong as the color suggest and neither is the flavor. A bit sweet and malty. Much like dark Kozel.
Mild aroma is sweet, roasted malts and some coffee. Low bitterness and light mouthfeel.

Dark brown red with tiny beige head that diminishes almost totally. Roasty and nicely bitter. very good bodied. good mouthfeel. a bit like light coke with no or little carbonation. quite smooth and sweet.

500 ml bottle. Medium head is light brown, fine textured and qite creamy. Dark brown liquid has shade of amber against the light. Light to medium sweet flavor with lightly roasted and sweet caramel malts. Also some coffee aromas. Very light bitterness in the finish. Mouthfeel is smooth but a bit watery and boring.

Bottle 0.5 l.
Bought Superbrugsen Hilleroed.
Dark brown with beige head. Rich carbonation. Weak malty aroma. Quite malty although I cannot determine the type of malt. Hobs almost absent.  Medium bitter. Not much mouthfeel.

Back from a Czech Republic pub-crawl this is part of my express ratings for the “typical” Světlý 11°- (Czech light Pils), Světlý 12°+ (Czech Pils), Polotmavý (Czech Amber Lagers) and Tmavý (Czech Black Lagers).  Non-typical beers will receive personalized descriptions after the express ratings.
----------------------------------------------------------------

How: Tap late-night (when all the good beer bars are closed) at some very cool pub in Prague but with a sucky beer selection

The look: Dark brown body with medium beige head

To me a typical Czech Tmavé (Czech Black Lager) is: Dark malts and barely any roastiness sensation.  Some dark fruits flavours (raisins with a little figs, dates and prunes) wrapped in smooth dark caramel (borderline toffee) and a subtle chocolate note.  A bit bready.  Moderately sweet without much hops presence and only a mild bitterness (voluntary unbalanced it seems).  Very smooth body, like a watery cream.

This one: As above but less of everything and a bit more toffee flavour.  Hints of black liquorice.  Body felt a bit empty.  Too clean.
Bottle. Pours dark brown with medium floffy head. Aroma is malty with some roastiness. Flavour is dark candy sugar and dark malts. Good bitterness. Pleasant dunkel.

draught at Moldava station, Ceske Rupublika. A smooth, dark, roasty flavoured beer, with a fairly dense, lasting, head. actually somewhat similar to a strong mild, with a coffee & chocolate aftertaste. certainly preferred this to any of the brewery’s pale offerings. tasted all the better for costing 35p, a tenth of the price in most UK pubs

Dark mahogany with a red hue and a huge, nice and creamy head. The aroma has notes of roasted malt and caramel. The flavour has sweetness and notes of roasted malt, caramel, candy sugar and a suitable, slightly citrussy, bitterness in the finish, and at the end also slightly dry. It’s smooth, mellow and pleasant.
las que puntúo con 2.4 son las que he probado pero no me acuerdo de la cata

High fluffy but lasting off-white head. Very dark red brown body. Lovely roasted barley malt aroma with a bit of caramel and hints of cocoa. Mild and yet hoppy caramel coffee flavor. Low carbonation. Long coffee like aftertaste.

Bottle in Moscow. Dark brown color, with a thin  beige foam. Sweet Coffee aroma and notes of chocolate and toffee. Flavor is balanced betwen sweetness and bitterness, notes of toffee and average carbonation, Mouthfeel is a little bitter at finish. Português: Cerveja marrom escura, com uma espuma bege e fina. Aroma adocicado de café e notas de chocolate e caramelo. Sabor balanceado entre o doce e o amargo, notas de caramelo e média carbonatação. Retrogosto um pouco amargo.
Cask. Roasted malt aroma, roasted malt taste. Boring and disappointing. 160208

500 ml bottle given to me by my friend JP upon his return from Prague, served a few minutes out of the fridge from a Coors Banquet fluted glass.  The voluminous dark tan head fills 1/3 of the glass, large-bubbled and decaying slowly atop the translucent molasses-hued body....faint burnt-grain notes, a hint of chocolate, but also alas some light skunkiness in the strong nose....the body is roasty, rather dry with just a bit of light chocolty residual sweetness certerpalate and fading rapidly....strong carbonation, fairly intense bitterness at the finish, all underdone by a very weak, thin body.  Potential, but....
Dark brown white huge short lasting beige head. Aroma has roasted malt and caramel. Sweet flavor with caramel, dark bread and roasted malt. Ends light bitter.

50 cL bottle. Pours dark brown with a little dense light bornw head. Lovely aroma of roasted malt and light hoppy fruity note. Flavour is smooth, almost chocolate like, malty and with a nice fruity note from the hops. Leads into a nice mild bitterness and roasted note in the finish.

Draught @ Roebuck, Hampton Hill, London TW12, UK. Clear medium red brown color with a average to large, frothy / creamy, good lacing, mostly lasting, beige head. Aroma is moderate malty, roasted, burnt, chocolate, coffee. Flavor is moderate sweet and light bitter with a average to long duration. Body is light to medium, texture is watery, carbonation is soft. (301207)

Bottle.Budweiser Budvar Premium Dark Lager.4.7% alkohol tartalom,11.9% fűszerezetség,0.5 literes üvegben.Kitöltve igazi "fekete" kinézete van a habja kemény és tömör csontfehér.Illatán már érződik a karamell édessége és a maláta is.Íze is hozza az orron át érzett aromákat.Utóízében van egy kis csoki és előjön egy kis komlós keserűség is.Finom,itatja magát de nem túl "különleges".

Bottle, thanks pivnizub. Roasted, light coffeeish and citric aroma. Dark claret, big fluffy brown head. Roasted malt and caramelized sugar in the foreground, ashen burned or smoked notes. Fairly light body, maybe I am just too used to bavarian Dunkel, but I feel it doesnt support the agressive roast and caramel at all. Quick cigar-finish with Saaz shining through.

I tasted this with Lady Crabapple after having endured the flavourless Erdinger Dunkel. Well, ’she who must be obeyed’ enjoyed this immensely and I must say, I think she has rather good taste in such matters.
Bottle from Morrisons. Dark brown with red hints. Aroma of roasted malt with some caramel. Flavour of coffee, milk chocolate and caramel with a bitter finish. Ok, but not hugely memorable.

I don’t know, what i can say about this beer.It looks very nice, the head is great, the aroma is fine roasted malt but the texture is a little vatery. In the flavour you can feel the taste of the roasted malt and some caramel&tobacco, coffee finish.
Pours dark brown with tan head. Aroma ahas malt sweetness. The flavor has some caramel and a slight bitterness. This was a nice easy drink.

On tap at the White Horse, Parson’s Green, 30th Dec 2007. Very near black with a solid cream coloured head. Smells of dark sweet malt with a hint of smokiness. Flavour of rich malt and tobacco. Not complex, but very drinkable. Smooth with a nice aftertaste too. Excellent stuff.

Bottle 0.5 l. Deep deep red, small beige head. Sour malty nose. Dryish roasted and a bit sour flavor. Nicely fresh dunkel, which isn’t too sweet. Some hoppiness detectable too. Pretty easy and enjoyable.

The bottle looks really good and the beer in the glass also. But the foam disappears very fast. The aroma is nearly mystic, very different. The flavor is much too malty, becomes really nasty. That’s why I have to say: Not a good beer!

Had this at the Galway beer festival, but didn’t really take any notes then so I had to buy this at the local off-license here in Dublin. 

Poured from a 500mL bottle with a nice dark amber color like a cola with a 1-finger head that looked very cola-ish as well. The head settled to a small film and stayed on top throughout the drink.  

Roasted malts and caramely hints fill the nose upon pour. A bit smokey too it smells like. 

The flavors that you can smell upon pouring come through right away in the taste too. It is a bit dry and not too full, but quite pleasant. Some sweetness & stickiness comes later on your tongue at the end of each sip along with a slight bit of sourness. Goes down easy with plenty of taste, not as heavy as I would have expected. 

I like this beer and think that I could drink more than one in a session-but I am not sure if I would drink it all night long.

(Draught at White Horse, Parson’s Green, London, 30 Nov 2007) Dark brown colour, almost black, with frothy pale brown head. Malty, roasted nose with toffee, chocolate and coffee. Roasted, malty taste with notes of coffee, chocolate and cola. Not very bitter and not overly sweet. Quite nice beer.

On draught in Prague
Black with an ample tannish head.  Aroma is smoky with some roasted maltiness.  The flavor matches,  Maybe a slight hint of chocolate, but not extreme.  Not too heavy.  Not bitter.  Very drinkable.

50cl bottle from Russia, thanks to Chad.   Grassy, roasty, and cocoa aroma.   Flavor is woody with some smoke, saltiness, roastiness, and a little chocolate.   Light to medium body is pretty smooth and rounded.   Some bitterness in the finish, but mostly from the roasted malts, and the hops don’t make much of an impact.   Also a little unclean and jumbled.   It’s alright, but I guess I just don’t like dunkels too much.
Black with a medium head. Light malt aroma. Light body.  Smokey, nutty and coffee notes. Enjoyable, although after two I felt the need to move on to something else.
Almost black beer with a thin fading off-white covering. Faintly smokey, roasty aroma but the flavour seems a little too washed out and watered down.

Draft @ U Medvidku, Prague.  Pours almost entirely opaque black with brown tones, lovely fluffy beige head that sticks around a while if you let it; almost like a lager stout: same chocolate roastiness, caramel and biscuit malts maple syrup, only lacking the heavy body and drawn out finish of a stout, which makes it a good bit more drinkable.  Goes exceptionally well with goulash.

Draught @ St. Albans BF. Due to many of my choices being already sold out, I was kindly given a glass to try while debating. I must say it was much better than expected, not amazing but my expectations were low. Sweet roasted malt and a bit of cocoa. Taste is much the same with a bit of coffee, caramel and some hop in the finish. Hey, don’t let the name fool you, they do a couple of good un’s...

On tap at Bedford Arms Speciality Beer House, Bedford. Dark brown with a lively beige head. Slightly eggy malt aroma. Rather watery ashy malt taste with traces of chocolate. A little bitterness. Not up to a decent porter.

500ml bottle: poured dark brown with a medium sized light brown head. Very rich smelling with roasted malts. Flavor is roasty, not near as rich as the aroma would suggest but still very nice. No residual sweetness lingering anywhere after swallowing. It’s not dry but in my opinion perfectly balanced. A very nice beer.

Dark brown colour on the looks with beige head. Malty nose, far hints of caramel. Round roasted malty flavour, some chocolate notes there too. Light sweetness, medium bitterness. Medium body, oily feel, average carbonation. Medium lasting after taste with that malty and light sweet-bitter touch Very good beer.
Pours dark slightly red, with a small quick disappearing head. Aroma has a lot of very roasted malts.

A Mes rate: 
50cl bottle from Grape Sense in Chalk Farm. Much more impressed with this than I was expecting. I’m a bit of a dark lager fan anyway but still, this is pretty tasty. Excellent semi-translucent dark brown / amber colour with a pretty stable mushroom coloured head. Really good sweet malt, chocolate and heavy coffee aroma with a very light sourness to it. Flavour very similar but with some light tobacco hoppage that to be honest lets it down just a little. A lick of card also does it no favours. Nice coffe malt finish brings it back. Decent stuff.

Bottle. Huge bubbly light brown head that mostly lasted. Good display of thick film like lacework. Somewhat clear dark mahogany color. Nice sniff of hops with notes of floral, hint of ashtray, light toasted malty notes, underlying caramel and grain sweet feel. Maybe even a hint of smoke in there as well.  Medium bodied with a light dry texture and an average carbonation. Light sweet and bitter flavor. Somewhat dry and light bitter finish.
Bottel.50cl. For me this one of the best dark lager, i have tasted, good aroma, fine body, and good head.
Tap... reminded me of a watered down Guinness. Not bad overall, but I like the light Budvar better.

0.5 l bottle. Dark brown colored body with, for dunkel quite big pale brown head. Nice aroma of roasted malt, caramel and coffee which are also present in the flavor. Somehow leaves watery impression, although not too much. Some bitterness present in the finish, which is  Not too much carbonation. Not bad beer, but empty.
//edit: Had it again, agree with everything said, just impaired the ratings.

(Bottle BB 07/06/08) Roasted malty and caramel aroma. Dark red brown colour and large, light brownish head with fair/good lacing. Roasted malty, caramel and coffee flavour with a hint of licorice. Lively carbonated, chalky and medium-bodied palate. Tasty, well-balanced brew! 09/08/07
Brown, beige collapsing head. Malty aroma. Sweet. Faintly metallic. Hard carbonation. Mild flavour. Roasted malts with notes of malty sweetness. Vague hoppy bitter finish. Watery palate. Boring.

First rating
(Draught at U Medvidku, Praha) 
Clear dark brown to black color, thick tan head. Sweet malty scent. Sweet malty and also roasted taste. A bit dry aftertaste. Medium mouthfeel and bitterness.
7/5/7/3/14=3.6

Rerate
(Draught at U Nová Ku, Plzen)
On June 27, 2008
Clear deep dark red color, fluffy tan head. Sweet, butterscotch, light roasted taste. Dry, roasted aftertaste. Butterscotch and sweet malty scent. A bit thin mouthfeel, low bitterness.
6/3/6/3/12=3.0

Combined rating: 6/4/6/3/13=3.2
Dark lagers are really cool. Herold is my favorite this Budvar agress with withmy liver too:) .Awesome roast malt taste :

Draft - Clear dark brown body, beige head; Medium sized nose, fresh malty, quite a bit of potato chips aroma; Fresh a bit thin body, bitter and strangely sweet; Medium long finish with fresh apple like hop aroma, milk chocolate malt aromas

Bottled (as Budweiser Budvar Premium Dark Lager).  Clear dark brown, small head. Lightly smokey nose. Light bodied with clean mouthfeel. Fairly dry, somewhat woody and roasty, notes of tobacco. Low-medium bitterness. Quite pleasant.
Bottle 0,5ltr bought in Karlovy Vary, Czech Rep: Fine dark amber looking Czech Dunkel with its roasted malts an caramel taste. Pretty good version from the ale from Tyne & Wear.
Bottle. Dark brown colour with medium creamy white mostly diminishing head. Roasted malt aroma with hints of chocolate. Sweet roasty flavor.

500ml bottle.
Dark reddy brown, rich froth for a head. Roasty and hoppy aroma. Wickedly bitter hoppy taste fights with punchy dark burnt malt taste for your attention. Don’t get me wrong, this is a well balanced fight. Anyway neither wins until the end of the aftertaste, as the bitterness survives longer. What’s this? The burnt malt wants a rematch?...
Bottle the cave. Aroma is roasted barley, dough and malted seeded bread, pale malts, caramelt and week coffee. Taste is similar baggish nature, good creamy mouthfeel once its warmed up.

This was my last beer on the trip, with dinner Praha 6 Budvar resturant.  A very pleasant .3L with the Gulash.  The medium dark body had some nice grainy bitterness to it.  Hops present thruout.  A quick sweet finish with a hoppy aftertaste.  Nice to have it from the tap. I would have had more if I didnt have to catch an early flight the next morning.

Blackish-brown with an off-white head of film. Sour aroma of a soggy piece of toasted dark rye. Mild sourness accompanies roasty malt flavor, sort of like weak, black coffee that’s no longer fresh. That’s not a bad thing, in this case. Light, sweet touch on the finish before bitterness kicks in, dry finish, with a malty-bitter aftertaste. Mouthfeel is lively and dry, a nice thing considering so many dunkels and schwarzes tend to run thin and wet. Not an exciting beer, but solid, sessionable, and it has some character.

Bottle, Dodgy Deli, Oxford. Rather dark brown with ruby highlights, abundant sticky tan head. Dry charred toast, sawdust, just a bit of herbal hops underneath. Soft smooth roast flavor. Sort of a one note roast character, like french roast coffee, but it’s a nice note. Just a touch of clean bitterness, abrupt finish.
on tap in Ceske Budejovice. dark red-bwornish colour. Roasted malts and chocolate, hoppy. Quite nice.

Dark clear look with a collapsing white head. Vague aroma of sweet malt, with some even weaker notes of roasted malts and something smoked. Seem overly carbonated. Flavor is refreshing with abit of bitter hops and some roasted notes.

Bottle at Benny.
Almost black with a beige head, some lacings. Aroma moderate malty (chocolate, roasted, caramel), light hoppy. Flavor light sweet and bitter. Watery.

My first dunkel - a nice pint. Light bodied, frothily carbonated lagerness with biscuity, roasted malt, and the soft Saaz bitterness on the palate - like a cross between a stout and a pilsener. Dry, refreshing, drinkable. Will have to try more dunkels to see how this compares but works for me.
Prauge-07. Decent dunkel. Easy drinking light body with roasted malt notes.
Dark brown colour, thick medium head. Very rich flavour with roasted coffee notes and almost no sweetness. Awesome.
Bottle at the hotelroom in Prague. Clear dark brown (almost black) - offwhite head. Burned, bread, ryebread, berries, dried fruits, raisins, dry. OK !!

Pint in the Bear & Billet, Chester. Was interested in this beer when I saw the tap. Coca cola appearance, not quite black but there abouts with an off white head. Rich syrup taste. Slight fruit and hoppy. An interesting and tasty brew.

Poured a dark reddy brown, with a good, though short-lived, off white head. Hoppy aroma with hints of roast nuts. Sweet, milky taste: nutty and a little chocolatey. A bitter hoppiness in the finish. Smooth palate, quite thin. Tasty dark lager. Nice hoppiness.

Bottle. dark brown colour, with medium head. Aroma oand taste of malts, coffee and caramel. Some notes of bitter chocolate and sweet malts. A bit more carbonation than Budjovicky Bohemia Dark. Tastes a bit like a christmas beer.

Bottle 0.5 L.
Dark brown body with reddish glows; large, creamy, light-brown head, mostly diminishing with a fair lacing.
Aroma is moterate-to-heavy malty (toasted with caramel hints) and lightly hoppy; notes of toffee and prunes.
Flavour is moderate bitter and light-to-moderate sweet; the bitter note becomes more dominant in the finish.
Light-to-medium body with a watery texture; soft carbonation.
On the average satisfactory, even if I had the feeling of an overall thin, dilute beer.
Amber, dark coloured brew. Malty, fruity aroma with a bit bitterness and fruity flavour. Avarage, but too watery.
50cl bottle. White semi-thick head, dark colour. Tastes and smells like roasted malts and a little bit chocolate. Aftertaste some what watery and metallic.

Deep Brown, Nice and balanced malty and fruity. With a heavy fruit front and a long finnish thats a little bitter (better in cask ,scored cask)
gbbf bottle tasting session... deeep ruby red ... rich smokey fruity lager ... rich flavour ... lager tones but some caramel and roast malts . 3.8

Bottle at home ... With Marko at the Mass(Mini) online tasting ... deep dark brown ....thin tan head ... sweet toffee roast ... little hay ... soft nutty malt ... dark caramel suger nose ... little too fizzy ... soft roast malts ... light caramel toffee ... little nutty malts ... light dates ... soft dark suger  3.4
(Draught at Cafe Evropa, Prague) Amber, offwhite/brownish head. A bit roasted malty aroma. Malty and hoppy flavor. roasted notes, some vanilla and chocolate. Somewhat bitter finish.
Delish!  What a tasty little black bugger this is from the Budvar boys!  Kind of dry and bitter like a stout, but refreshingly drinkable like a lager.  Very strange; very nice!

500ml bottle from Morrisons - branded as Budweiser Budvar Czech Dark Lager.A dark chestnut with a slight reddish glow, and a beige head; thin aroma of roast malt; in the mouth there is more chocolate malt, but still rather thin; leaving a dry aftertaste. Less than I expected from Budwieser Budvar.
Very lively on pouring from the bottle.The large head took some time to settle down. Reasonably pleasant combination of tastes but all round not that impressive.

0.5l green bottle, purchased at the nearby Mercator mall. As Budweiser Budvar Premium Dark Lager.
  A new foreign beer that isn’t a pale lager and can be easily found. Now that’s something you don’t see here often...  It poured a dark...say...red/brown colour, with a nice, big, thick spongy tan head that went away at a medium pace. Taste... roasty, hoppy (fresh/herbal), and just a touch of cocoa and toffee. Taste... didn’t impress me.... thinnish taste, metallic hints, powdery, dry coffee and chocolate hints, some roastiness and some honey. Hops are noticable in the background and the aftertaste but they’re not very prominent... but that’s ok for the style I guess. Hoppy/roasty long but faint finish. Ok, but failed to impress me.

Bottled(500ml). -as Budweiser Budvar Premium Dark. Dark brown coloured, small beige head, nice coffee nose. Roasted malt and strong coffee aroma with bitter chocolate and earthy notes. Dry and mild bitterish coffee finish.

(bottled, 4.7% ABV, as Budw. Premiun Dark Lager) Clear, dark mahogany colour with a big and slowly lacing beige foamy head. Sweet and roasty dark malt aroma with a touch of cacao and distinctive herbal and slightly grassy hops. Bitter flavour, roast-malty taste with notes of caramel, chocolate and coffee; rather slim bodied with a well-carbonated mouthfeel; dry and bitter finish with caramel,  a hoppy blend and chocolate in the aftertaste. Likeable.

Bottle, from Morrisons. Deep red brown, moderate lasting off white head and gentle condition. Pleasant earthy roasted barley a touch of phenols and low sweet chocolate with a touch of fruitiness in the nose, dry and earthy roasted barley in the mouth with a balancing sweet chocolate and caramel note, dry roastiness and low caramel sweetness lingering in the finish.
Bottle. Dark brown colour with a medium off-white head. Aroma and flavour of roasted malt, hops, chocolate and caramel.

Bottle. Dark brown colour with a mostly lasting large off-white head. Sweet aroma of roasted malts, caramel and bitter hops. Flavour is crisp, malty and roasty, caramellic sweet with bitter hops. Bitter-sweet finish.

Bottle. Dark brown, almost black. Thin light tan head, dissipates. Nose of slightly sour malts, some bitter hops. Chocolate and roasted malts, lots of dark chocolate malt in the taste. Very clean. Quite an excellent drinkable dunkel.
Dark brown color, medium off-white head. Aroma of roasted malt, rye. Bit sweet taste, but also bitter. Good dunkel.

Bottle, Premium Dark Lager. Aroma of bohemian hops, dark caramel malts/some rye. Clear brown coloured with a lasting off-white-brown head. Taste is sweet Hoppy, caramel malty and some rye in it. Thin bodied. Quite okay actually.

A dark, chocolate brown coloured beer with reddish tints and a thickish white head. A light, toasted malt nose, with hints of caramel and a nutty toffee aroma. The taste is bitter, and fizzy on the tongue. Caramel, toffee and a nutty, slightly sweet, malty flavour comes through. The finish is light, fizzy and a touch bitter. Refreshing when served cold. (Bottle - courtesy of Mark & Marie @ The Fox & Hounds, Heacham, Norfolk).

Bottled as Premium Dark Lager. Chocolate aroma with a hint of cola. Dark brown color, beige head, very nice lace. Chocolate, light sweet, light malty, light bitter, light roasted, medium body. Didn’t really like it when I started but half way the bottle I got used to it.

Draught in Prague
Dark color; thick head. Light aroma and taste, just some roasted malt; weak, almost watery.
Dark brown and clear. Has a medium beige head, medium lasting. Not much aroma, only some burnt notes. Flavor is real good, yeasty and malty and burnt.

Bottle. As ’Premium Dark Lager’. Pours a clear red/brown with a big beige/brown head. Sweetish and dryish aroma with notes of yeast, malt, cereals and hops. Sweetish flavour. Roasted notes. Bitter finish with roasted notes. Sort of like a stout. Lingering notes of apple. Seems rather ordinary when you break it down in the different categories, but overall this is quite nice and drinkable. 08-12-06.

Bottled: Light malty and roasty aroma. Black color, lively carbonation, Creamy, brown head. Flavor is malty with light sweetness and fruitiness. Dark chocolate, coffee and roasted malt in the end. Roasty finish, dry.

Near black colored, slight red hints. Medium sized beige head. Obvious chocolate with sweetness and caramel. Thin to medium bodied. After strongly chocolaty aroma, nicely roasted flavor with touch of chocolate. Aftertaste dries with chocolate and caramel, slight metal tones there too. Crispy palated and refreshing dunkel.
I like this dunkel beer. Tastes good and is also refreshing.................

Draught at Dr. Louise, Esbjerg.
Creamy white fair mostly lasting head. Redbrown colour. Heavy malty toasted caramellic aroma. Nice powerfull chocolate flavor. Average finish. Watery palate. Nice dunkel.
Dark ruby color, ivory head, Hints of chocolate and faintly musty, smoky malt,..Not very sweet, balanced but a bit dull. Light to medium-bodied,..nice one

Bottle from Booths, Knutsford.  Not being a massive fan of Budvar beers (IMO vastly over-rated) I thought i’d give this a go to see if they could make a decent go of it.  Admittedly it’s better than the lacklustre 12 or the bland 10 but it’s not a patch on beers like Herold or Zubr.  A good roasty, caramel and malty aroma is followed by a dryish, toasty, slightly chocolatey and roasted flavour with a subtle bitterness in the malty, burnt finish.  Overall a little too understated for me but it’s not a bad beer by any stretch.

Bottle picked up at Morrissons, Aylesbury 8th August 2006, and drank this in a field at Cropredy, Fairport Conventions Cropredy Festival Saturday 12th August. Dark brown with a slightly off white coloured head that was quite big and frothy, some nice bitter chocolate aromas, very good bitter and roasted taste with nice maltyness coming through, very good, have had this in Prague on draft as well and really enjoyed.

Green bottle.  Sweetly malty aroma with caramel, toffee, and chocolate powder.  Very dark brown with a lacing light brown head.  Crisp and fizzy.  Predominately bitter.  Powdered cocoa and dark chocolate, toffeeish grit.  Weakling seems to be overcompensating.  Not extremely harmonious. Very dry finish.  Taste lingers long .  A little too reminiscent of cola.
Bottle.  Smooth dark beer with a nice white head.  The aroma is milky and coffee, and the flavour is quite dry, bitter coffee with a slightly milky stout quality.  Overall a nice beer.

Hugely attractive aroma of roasted malt and chocolate. Rich blackish body with a creamy beige head. Beautifully rounded interplay of pale, Munich, caramel and (most assertively) roasted barley malt. Got so excited I spilt it all over my notebook. Essentially a robustly bitter stout with a malty sweetness in the background. Big, roasty, smooth- bodied...and impossible to resist.

Bottled.  A black coloured beer with a reasonable whitish head at first but that disappears fairly quickly.  The aroma is dry and roasty; pretty stout like really.  The tste is also roasty but this time there’s a little lactic character.  A tad smoky and really quite tasty.  Thinner in the body than the aroma promises but still a good drink.Score 3.5
Subsequent rating also scored 3.5.

Pint poured at the Jolly Gardeners in Putney (London), a carbonated black with a good frothy light tan head. Not a strong aroma, some caramal if anything. Some light roasted flavours, the carbonation made it refreshing, with dry bitter finishing. Served cold, was reasonably enjoyable in the 30-degree heat.

Bottle.  Dark brown with red tints and a beige head.  Aromas are chocolate and wheat malts with light roast character.  Flavours are chocolate and lemon with cola.  Gritty and prickly.  Some light coffee.  Dry and refreshing.  Decent, but not quite as good as Herold Dark.

Dark tawny in colour, with a firm pale coffee coloured head. There is a pronounced fruity nose with some underlying malt...however it’s much lighter than I expected, a slight maltiness flts across the tastebuds and is replaced by an astringent acidity, the finish is minimal. Ok I suppose, but not a patch on the other stuff. Morrisons

Bottle from one of the supermarkets. Dark brown colour. Aroma is sweet caramel and a touch of roast. To taste it’s sweet, caramel and toffee with some toasted notes and a bit of burnt malt. Has that telltale boiled sweet character that ruins these boiled beers for me. According to the bottle the name is a protected geographical indication, but something this blandly average could be brewed anywhere.

Draught at Københavnske Øldage 2006. Very dark reddish brown colour with a nice head. Little sour and some roastedness at the aroma. Also light roasted flavour. Ends up quite dry and some bitter. Not as good as theres normal Budvar.

(On tap) Beautiful, clear mahogany with a small, off-white head. Weak aroma of roasted malt. Rather high carbonation. Weak - very weak - notes of roasted malt. Dry finish. For a brewery that produces the world’s best Pilsener this truly was a disappointment. 190506
Draught. Almost black with very little head. Has a sweet, caramel based aroma. It is a bit sharp in the taste, adding some citric tones to a very staying taste.

Bought it in the Trink Gut in Nordhorn for only € 0,70 a bottle, named Budvar Premium Dark Lager. Dark brown color, creamy head. Roasted malt and grass in the aroma. Coffee, roast, apple and a grassy hopbitterness in the flavor. Also caramel. Thinnish, but certainly has complexity. Very well made dunkel.

Bottled, pasteurised, 500ml. Black beer with pale head. Nice malty sweet aroma leading to a big fruity flavoured beer, plenty of caamel and licquorice and fruity notes. Burnt charcoaly flavors too giving a bitter finish. Very pleasant.

On Tap at the Crown Inn, Oakengates 20/08/2005
Dark coloured and hoppy. Crisp on the palate with a slightly dry full malt finish.

Biggish offwhite creamy head takes some time to settle. Clear dark red body. Clear, faint, sweetish aroma with faint hints of roastiness. Deep, sweetish yet quite fresh taste with a light, clean roastiness and some licorice. Acidic aftertaste. Milky mouthfeel. Excellent dark lager. (On tap somewhere in Prague.)

dark badbwoy poured at the SIDE DOOR in Dresden. Dark black pour. nice beige head. Roasted toffee and coca. Some nuttiness and roastiness..nuyyyyy not too shabby. When I first saw it I was like eww Budweiser. Then I be wisened up and was like, BUDWAR!!! zazuWEIW  anyways, damn german keyboard...this was very easy and a pleasure to drink

Draught at Soldaten Svejk, Stockholm. Dark brown with a rich beige head. Light roasty aroma of cocoa and white chocolate, hints of coffee. Malty and a bit fried flavour of choclate and white bread. Medium to light bitter aftertaste.
Keg at the Swan in the Rushes, Loughborough. Dark brown colour with a foamy, regenerating head. Quite malty, roasted and sweet. Thin bodied and drinkable. Had more than one.
Tap. Brown color with a beige head. The taste is a sweet but rather thin malty body and sweet caramel notes.

Nutty, biscuity malts greet the nose.  Clear mahogany brown with low but lasting tan head that recedes to partial cover.  Biscuity, bready and roasted malt flavours compete for attention.  Medium body is dry and quite well-attenuated with lively but soft carbonation.  Sampled at GBBF 2005.

On tap at "U obory", Jabkenice: Very dark amber coloured, medium sized nice lacing head; clean malty aroma with a tinge of molasses, lively caronation; slightly sweetish, distinctive malty taste; drier, bitter aftertaste (with a tinge of chocolate); very well balanced between maltiness and bitterness; quite full bodied. A very good classical Bohemian Dunkel !
Draught. Brown coloured. Malty aroma. Sweet and malty flavour with notes of caramel. Soft mouthfeel.
Draught (GBBF): Mild coffee aroma. Dark brown with a brown head. Sweet coffee and choc flavours. Medium bodied, quite nice.

On tap in Jicin:



The Lure:
Lots of foam, but quickly receding. Roasted berries galore conquering the caramel build-up. Grilled meats are evoked, but that just may be my screaming hunger.



The Festivities:
Earthy berries fill the room, as caramel cleans up in the far corner. Light roastiness fades into a shy aftertaste. There’s nothing exciting here, but this is still a well-made and quenching dunkel.



Transcendence:
An average meal still procures some sort of enjoyment.

Draught @ GBBF 2005: Brownish coloured with a small brown head. Is sweet, cocoaish, friuty and has some light roasty notes. Has a smooth and pleasant mouthfeel. Endson a sweet fruity light roasted note A good dunkel, thats quite easy to drink.

Just called Budvar Dark in the bar I sampled this one in.  Based on taste, I’m assuming this is the same beer.  Poured out black with a big white creamy head.  Smelled of pepper, nuts and has some floral notes.  Tasted of caramel and chocolate with some bitter citrussy notes.  Peppery finish.

Draught@GBBF 05’. I liked this stuff, subtle but very nice. Lightly roasty, choclatey, and ever so slightly smoky. Very sofft mouthfeel, with some hop bitterness in the finish. Liked it very much and its something i could drink a few of.

Cask at GBBF
Very dark brown.  Not a lot of aroma, but good malts though in the mouth flavour with some burntness and coffee.  Not a bad dunkel with a lasting coffee finish. 3.1 Re-rate bottle at home during the Budvar tasting.  Good malt and good choc.

[Draught, Great British Beer Festival] Hints of chocolate and faintly musty, smoky malt, but not much in the aroma. Dark ruby in colour, with a thin, ivory head, though I suspect the head may be down to the way it was poured.

A sweet, caramel flavour, with hints of chocolate and some maltiness, but very thin-bodied. I was expecting more from this, to be honest, given the brewer.
Draught at Microbar, Battersea. Very dark with a small pale biege head. Smoky, roast aroma, hint of chocolate. Saaz hop as well. Slightly sweet caramel flavour, some earthiness.

[on tap in Czech Republic]
Almost black, reddish caramel with a lacy, beige cover.  Sweet malt and coffee fill the aroma, leaving no room for hops, but some hazlenut notes.  Toasty malt flavour with a blend of malt and hops bitterness that linger.  Toasted toffee.  Light to medium body and fairly dry.  Medium carbonation.
